title: Between 24 October 2017 and 1 February 2018, will Bahrain, Oman, Qatar, or Saudi Arabia have their long-term issuer rating downgraded by S&P, Moody's, or Fitch?
preds: Regional stability is lowering after the Saudi purge and Lebanon intervention.

Revenues of these countries increased by 10-20%, oil prices are more favorable for them (in second half of 2017 year). Small period of time - 2.5 months.
Downgrading three of them (Qatar, Oman, and Bahrein) has small probability

Question has not clear vision of occurrence of resolving answers. There are 4 subjects and 3 objects in this question. Subjects in question: B, O, Q, or Saudi Arabia. There are two commas between them. Many people with high probability on that question think answer will occur if downgrading occur only in one country. But description of question has not words “or” between B O Q. They has only commas among them: that way of writing implies the inclusion of all 3 subjects (B O Q) in the list necessary for the appearance of answer, they must be all downgraded. Because/ if there are not all 3 countries, this will not be a complete list. Without one of them it must be written word “or” for clear understanding. Same picture with 3 objects (S, M or F). 
I applied the following draft calculations, probability for each country can be changed. At the same time, Oman has taken probability 100% (my opinion: it is still in doubt).
Probability for 4 subjects P(BandOandQ, SA)=P(B)*P(O)*P(Q)+P(SA)
Probability for 3 objects P(SandM, SA)=P(S)*P(M)+P(F)
Probability for question P=P(subjects)*P(objects)
P for question=(0.3*1*0.4+0.2)*(0.3*0.2+0.4)=0.32*0.9=0.288

Question has not exact answer. Will downgrading occur in  all three countries (Bahrein, Oman or Qatar)? or in one of those countries? or in Saudi Arabia? Question has not clear clarification which event will trigger the answer occurence. And there may be some questions about notion of “downgrading” and “grade”
Between 24 October 2017 and 1 February 2018, will Bahrain, Oman, Qatar, or Saudi Arabia have their long-term issuer rating downgraded by S&P, Moody's, or Fitch?
Recent macroeconomic developments have raised concerns regarding the debt profile of several GCC countries (Reuters, Reuters, Reuters, Gulf News, Bloomberg). Long-term foreign currency and/or local currency issuer ratings will count. Revisions to outlook will not count.
Same question about credit agencies: one of them, two of them or all three credit agency?
Mwokasch has good opinion about Oman rating

------- 11/10/2017 Update ------- Looks like I nailed this one: S&P downgraded Oman from BB+ to BB (11/10/2017)
https://tradingeconomics.com/oman/rating
https://countryeconomy.com/ratings

As predominately oil renter states, with the market price of hydrocarbons on the rise after a long dip, economies of the GCC will strengthen into the new year. An enduring risk of regional armed conflict places the stability of gulf markets outside certainty.

Qatar has larger weight  in answer of this question
World bank: High frequency data suggests that the economy is adjusting. In September, Qatar inaugurated the US$7.4 billion Hamad seaport, thereby securing alternative trading routes. Investor confidence in the currency peg remains anchored by the country’s large stock of liquid external assets worth nearly US$180 billion (of a total stock of close to US$300 billion), which have helped to contain the increase in risk premiums on sovereign and corporate debt. The hydrocarbon sector, which constitutes 80 percent of export earnings and 90 percent of government revenues, has been largely unaffected. Fiscal consolidation is continuing, albeit, according to some reports, at a slower pace. The fiscal deficit is projected to decline to 5.7 percent in 2017 from over 8 percent in 2016
http://www.worldbank.org/en/country/gcc/publication/qatar-economic-outlook-october-2017
Exports from Qatar increased 20 percent from a year ago to QAR 20.6 billion in September 2017, boosted by higher sales of petroleum oils and oils obtained from bituminous minerals, not crude (118.7 percent) and crude (81.5 percent), and other groups of commodities (21.8 percent). Among major trading partners, sales went up to Singapore (196.4 percent), China (76 percent), South Korea (10.9 percent), Japan (6.4 percent) and India (1.2 percent).
https://tradingeconomics.com/qatar/exports

this is interesting: "Targeting a nation’s [here, Qatar's] economy using financial manipulation would be a dramatic break from traditional norms of diplomacy and even warfare. The plan the document presents is far-fetched and appeared to have been put together by someone with little or no experience trading in credit and currency markets, two industry veterans who reviewed the plan for the Intercept said. Both were granted anonymity because speaking to the press could jeopardize their employment. “I can’t believe they put this on paper,” one of the credit veterans added. “They are talking about colluding to manipulate markets.”" https://theintercept.com/2017/11/09/uae-qatar-oitaba-rowland-banque-havilland-world-cup/

comments:
UAE not included in this Q, but obviously with Bahrain and KSA on the blockade.
Statement about norms above seems bafflingly naive; perhaps I don't understand it.
Re comment of "industry veteran" above, I presume states get held to different legal standards, but again, don't know.

I found a more reliable quote about what negative outlook means: ". S&P said: "Our negative outlook on our rating on the US sovereign signals that we believe there is at least a one-in-three likelihood that we could lower our long-term rating on the US within two years." So that's only a 16.67% chance of a downgrade within a year, and 8% within 6 months. I am reducing my estimate somewhat, also due to oil price increases possibly providing some relief. http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/economics/gilts/8459092/What-do-credit-ratings-mean.html

Qatar was put on negative watch in June and July.
https://tradingeconomics.com/qatar/rating According to Investopedia, negative watch means a 50% chance of downgrade within 3 months. However I can't find a more reliable source for this.
https://www.investopedia.com/terms/n/negative-watch.asp Transition matrices from Moody's show a cumulative chance of downgrade, within 1 year, from aaa3 rating, is 5.3%. The probability of any transition (ie up or down) is 11.5%. But since outlook is negative, we should assume upgrade probability is zero, and consider 11% as just a transition probabilty, and down as a given. Can use this as a lower bound on probability (divided by 3 to account for shorter than a year time period, so ~4%). This gives a very conservative base rate of 4%. 
https://www.moodys.com/sites/products/DefaultResearch/2006800000445742.pdfx There have also been some attempts to model transition probability, but I might leave digging up the numbers needed to feed into their model for a later exercise.
https://arxiv.org/pdf/0912.4621
http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.488.9725&rep=rep1&type=pdf Qatar is just one country, and this question asks 'or', so probabilities are cumulative. And the likelihood of a downgrade for one or more other countries seems fairly high, particularly since there are wide discrepancies between the different agencies' ratings, which we know don't persist in the average (hat tip @mwokasch).

Fitch has rated Bahrain at a higher level than the other 2 rating agencies and for a longer period of time. Perhaps a downgrade is due by the end of the year. http://www.worldbank.org/en/country/gcc/publication/bahrain-economic-outlook-october-2017
Despite austerity measures, Bahrain remains the most vulnerable GCC country in the face of low oil and bauxite prices due to its limited savings and high debt levels, leaving it exposed to financing risks.

I don't think Saudi Arabia's rating will be going anywhere in the next 3 months, but there is room for a downgrade with the others. Bahrain: Moody's downgraded them 2 notches in July 2017, outlook negative. S&P last downgrade was December 2016, but outlook went to negative in June 2017. Fitch's last downgrade was one notch in June 2016, outlook continues to be negative. (All three agencies give a different rating, with Moody's being the lowest, all negative outlook.) https://countryeconomy.com/ratings/bahrain Oman: Moody's downgraded one notch July 2017. S&P downgraded one notch May 2017. Fitch no recent downgrade but outlook went negative in June 2017 (looks like Fitch did not rate them before 2017). (S&P rating 2 notches lower than other agencies, all give negative outlook.) https://countryeconomy.com/ratings/oman Qatar: Moody's downgraded May 2017 but outlook went negative July 2017. S&P downgraded June 2017, outlook went negative August 2017. Fitch downgraded one notch August 2017. (Effectively same rating by all three agencies, all negative outlook.) https://countryeconomy.com/ratings/qatar Saudi Arabia: Moody's downgraded May 2016, nothing since. S&P downgraded 2 notches in February 2016, stable outlook. Fitch downgraded one notch in March 2017, stable outlook. (S&P's rating is two notches lower than Moody's or Fitch, but all three give stable outlook.) https://countryeconomy.com/ratings/saudi-arabia Link to the other, similar question in Geopolitical Challenge:
https://www.gjopen.com/questions/550-between-8-august-2017-and-7-august-2018-how-many-governments-from-among-bahrain-oman-qatar-and-saudi-arabia-will-have-their-long-term-issuer-rating-downgraded-by-s-p-moody-s-or-fitch

There seems to be quite the bifurcation of results, but I haven't seen many numbers supporting the answers, so I'll try to supply a bit of my thinking on the subject. My Process
1) I've pulled together the ratings of each of the 142 countries and standardized the ratings on a scale of 1 - 20.  
2) I've cross compared the differences in ratings for the 142 countries.  This resulted in 280 different cross comparisons of ratings (i.e., S&P vs. Moody's; S&P vs. Fitch; Moody's vs. Fitch).
3) I bucketed the  the size of the discrepancies (i.e., No difference, 1 rating differential, 2 rating differential, 3, 4, 5, etc.) This resulted in the following distribution: 
0 Rating Difference:  159 occurrences (57% of sample)
1 Rating Difference:    93 occurrences (33% of sample)
2 Rating Difference:    22 occurrences (8% of sample) 
3 Rating Difference:      4 occurrences (1% of sample) 
4 Rating Difference:      0 occurrences (0% of sample) 
5 Rating Difference:      2 occurrences (0% of sample) Now why did I do this?  Well, because only Qatar had no rating differential.  The other countries had rating differentials of 2 ranks or greater.  Thus, these three countries make up the vast majority of the sample of countries outliers, which should get corrected via downgrades.  Given that only one needs to be corrected the "right probability" of a downgrade would be:  Probability of a Downgrade = 1-[(.08)*(.08)*(.01)] = 100% Note: Yes, I acknowledge that I have not taken into account the timeline, but 4 months feels sufficient to rectify a very high probability event. --------------------------------- 11/10/2017 Update ---------------------------- Looks like I nailed this one: S&P downgraded Oman from BB+ to BB (11/10/2017)
https://tradingeconomics.com/oman/rating
https://countryeconomy.com/ratings

I am a beginner in issuer ratings. Anyways, given that the ratings were recently downgraded, I expect that Saudi Arabia and Qatar will not be downgraded further. Bahrain and Oman: Oman is now junk. Maybe Bahrain can be further downgraded.

I'm just copying my answer below from the extremely similar question the CFA Society already asked. I realize the parameters are different by the basic data is the same. Basically I think there are serious risks to three of the countries over this time frame. Bahrain-In the last year all three ratings agencies have downgraded their outlook and Moody's cut their rating two weeks ago. I think it get's cut by an agency in the next year. 
Oman-All three agencies are negative and two have already cut their rating this year. I think it get's cut by an agency in the next year. 
Qatar-All three agencies are negative with Fitch and S&P extremely negative (negative watch) and one has already cut their rating this year. I think it extremely likely that it get's cut by an agency in the next year. 
Saudi Arabia-The outlook is stable for all three agencies, unless the political or economic situation deteriorates sharply I don't see a cut in the next year.
Not clear why this would happen, but I suppose if it were clear it wouldn't be a question....
